content:
I'd also suggest just cleaning up the description. Use the first paragraph just to describe the problem, then list two or three examples, each on its own line. You've got three examples, but they're just kind of mixed in with the description. 

And fix the formatting of the sentence that starts with "Essentially". Put "x" and "X" in blue.
Does the length of s always exactly equal the number of Xs in f? Does s only ever contain letters? Based on the test cases it appears so. These constraints should be specified somewhere.
The problem is not well described and the specifications are not explicit enough. Write some constraints and more test cases.

Possibly change

"The input may also have periods or other symbols or letters in them - these should be skipped." 

to

"The form may also have periods or other symbols or letters in them - your program should output these characters as well."

Otherwise, solid problem and description. Good job.

Love it! Simple and elegant. A few things before I approve:

- The validators should test the same thing as the sample test. For example, Validator 1 introduces characters other than X, while the corresponding sample test does not, and Validator 3 contains spaces while the corresponding sample test does not.
- I would put the form f after the string s in input - on shortest mode it's easier that way.
- I think this could be valid for reverse mode :)
Please let me know if you like the problem, and if there are any changes you'd recommend!

Thank you for the feedback! I have made the changes you have suggested. Actually, I had a question as well: What is the difference between the tests and the validators? I'm not sure about what they do.
Thank you! I have made the suggested changes.
Are there any specific places you think requires description?
I have added some more details. Thank you for the feedback!

Firstly, would the form ever "request" more letters than the string has? Secondly, would the string ever be too long to "fill" into the form? also, the description says "special characters", although it's really not describing special characters since our special characters are x and X in this case.
Alright, thanks. I've changed the reference to just characters, and in the constraints it mentions that the number of x's always equals the length of the string.

Hey!

Basically it's a hard-coding prevention mechanism. During an actual clash, people will only see the tests. They get to run them as many times as they want to make sure they work. But when they submit their final solution, what actually runs are the validators, which are meant to evaluate the same conditions as the sample tests but with slightly different data.

This is so that if someone hardcoded the solution to a test case (say, if input is "sAmMyJr", return "SammyJr"), they get no credit for it. However, if the solution is not hardcoded, it is important that the sample tests accurately describe what will be actually tested in the validators, which is why they need to be similar. Otherwise you could pass the sample tests but not the validators and get a lower score than expected.
